Pre-order the NexiGo Aurora Pro MKII at: https://lmg.gg/AuroraProMKII

Wow, AMD. It may have taken Nvidia screwing up the RTX 50 series launch, but with the prices and performance you showed us today, you might just have a shot at gaining ground in the graphics card wars with the new Radeon RX 9070 XT.

comments.text:
I actually got to try NVIDIA app after being on team read for so long, since 2019 (it sounds recent until you realize it’s 7 years ago.).  I was experiencing crashing with my Radeon RX 6800 XT so I had to get something that could play DX 12 Ultimate game while I waited for the GPU situation to resolve its self. The only GPU I could find at MSRP was the lowly GeForce RTX 4060.  The Nvidia app is inferior to AMD’s Adrenaline App in every way possible. I also found out that AMD’s HDR just looks better than NVIDIA. It’s not just the extra power from the 4K capable card vs a 1080p card.  I would love to put a beefier GeForce to the HDR test but I don’t have one. 

If AMD actually pulls this off and ray tracing significantly improved.  Then LTT can dunk on NVIDIA all they want 😂


I fixed the crashing on my 6800XT.  But when the 4060 can play Wukong with Ray tracing on medium at a playable frame rate at 1080p high. and the 4k to 1440p raster beast from 2020 whimpers to unplayable. 😅

comments.text:
So I have a bit of a conundrum. I've recently upgraded into a totally new build. My old one was an I7 7700k and a GTX 1070. It was a good PC and still played things relatively well despite its age to this day, but I finally had the capability to upgrade. I've purchased and put together a new build with a 9800X3D CPU, new DDR5 6000mhz RAM with a brand new case and MB, and it runs great...but I have no GPU to put in it. The 50 series are all sold out or being scalped, the 40 series shot up dramatically in price after the 50 series "released" and I don't want to buy a 30 series or cards around that age, because I don't want to have to upgrade it again soon.

On a whim I signed up for that Nvidia email program where you can tell them you're interested in their 5080/5090 GPUs and they'll randomly select some people to reply and sell a card directly. I chose a 5080 because there is no way I'm spending 2k on a single GPU.

Now the issue is, do I just go out and buy a 9070 XT for slightly cheaper and potentially be able to have a slightly less powerful card *right now*, or wait to see if I get chosen to buy a 5080 that is more power and has better upscaling/AI tech and longevity, but has other risks associated with it?

My 1070 wants to go to its eternal rest, please help me decide
comments.author: @MrPerson61

comments.author: @Boss_Fight_Index_Channel

comments.text:
@ do you not wan’t to know.  Like you’d rather not know, than be burdened by viewing graphs?    

Also you assume an amount of overwhelm of information,  AMD could present the information in any number of ways.   Their presentation of 30 games isn’t some fixed variable.   They could do something as simple as an average. 

People aren’t $700 gpu buyers or $500 gpu buyers.  They would all like to spend as little as possible, they’re buyers of performance and cost/performance.  A 700 series buyer might be the same as a 900 series buyer, if the value proposition was right, or if hit a specific performance target like maxing out the frame rate of their monitor in their favorite game. 

Just a comparison with the GRE model doesn’t give the buyer the breadth of relevance that people actually look at when considering all their various upgrade options and how the budget can be spread across all kinds of things.   

Very rarely does $700 for a gpu and only a gpu come into someones budget. It’s a wholistic thing.  

Even if gift giving from parents is a factor, they either show up heavy or show up soft.  Either giving no choice, or a dynamic choice which requires the full set of options. 

Every $500 gpu buyer is also a $300 gpu buyer, and maybe more if the value proposition is there.  That’s why so many products offer a $50 difference between skews, to make the more expensive model seem worth the little bit extra.

comments.text:
Narrator: We're buying ghosts. Empty shelves. Plastic promises.
Tyler: We're buying GPUs. Ghosts, I said. Phantoms. They don't exist.
Narrator: To play games.
Tyler: Games? You call that code vomit a game? Glitchy, broken, unfinished.
Narrator: Games that are...not optimized.
Tyler: Optimized? That's a corporate lie. They sell you the problem, then sell you the "fix". A loop. A goddamn hamster wheel.
Narrator: And not fun.
Tyler: Fun? You're chasing pixels, man. Pixels that mock you. They taunt you with their lag, their crashes, their empty promises. You're buying the illusion of fun, and you're paying a premium for it.
Narrator: So we buy them.
Tyler: We buy them because we're slaves. Slaves to the shiny. Slaves to the next big thing. Slaves to the lie that more power equals more life.
Narrator: And we wait.
Tyler: We wait, like addicts. Junkies for a fix that never comes. We wait for the patch, the driver update, the miracle that will never arrive.
Narrator: And we play.
Tyler: We play because we're desperate. Desperate for something, anything, to fill the void. But the void is a hungry beast. It only gets bigger.
Narrator: And we're broke.
Tyler: Broke in spirit, broke in pocket. Broke in the head. We're buying our own damn chains.

I would consider the extra power and heat cost of the XT board to be a liability.  I'm looking at a RX 6900 XT card that kept shutting my system down from heat faults, so I had to pull it from my system.

comments.author: @scottk3292

comments.text: make sure you have at least 2 front fans, 1 back, 1 top rear (4 total)
comments.author: @Boss_Fight_Index_Channel

comments.text:
@Boss_Fight_Index_muki  Thanks, I've got four of the really huge fans, plus more on the back.  My system itself stayed very cool.  The problem was the video card fans wouldn't spin up when it started getting warm (despite my changing all that in the board settings).  Then the fans on my 6900 would go ballistic and sound like a vacuum cleaner for about 1 second, then the machine would shut down.  I monitored the hotpoint while firing up PlanetCrafter Prologue, and it shot up to 113 C almost instantly, then shut my machine off.  It just couldn't handle some games.  So it was definitely some problem where my power supply was basically being dumped through the GPU or similar.  I bet some load-control circuitry had failed.  I had to set most of my games to max 30fps to avoid the heat issues.
Anyway, I'll be glad to get a new, performant card and see how that goes.

I hope the reviews next week are positive.
I really want to upgrade... depending on the EU Tax and prices and stock and bots/scalper, I maybe can upgrade or not... 
I am just not sure if 9070 or 9070 XT.
I would say with only "50$" difference, they obvious choice is the 9070 XT with 20% better performance.
But I only have a 650 PSU and recommended for the XT is 750.
But I also put all my parts in pcpartpicker and instead of my 3070 I put  a 4080 super in, which have 320 watts. And the estimate is 504. So based on that I would be fine, since it should be 488 with a 9070 XT... hmm...

But maybe I am leaning more towards a 9070 no XT, which technically makes no sense, because it's "only" 50$ cheaper but with 20ish% less performance.
But I would guess that many would rather go for the Xt because of that, and that could lead to Xt seeling out in no time if stock isn't that great.
+ out side of 4090 and 5080, if AMD is to be believed a 5080 is just like 10 ish % better than a 9070 XT. So based on that a non XT is like 30 ish % slower than the best "non overkill" gpu on the market.
And since I only care for 1440p and 60 fps, I feel like these 20% difference between a non XT and XT won't be that huge, because if your non XT will struggel a lot, than probably because the Game is just badly optimized so the XT will probably not be that much better off.

comments.text:
Aight, gonna make a guess on what's to happen over the next year or so after this launch. We'll see if it's accurate at all in about 4 months minimum, 6 months maximum. 

Simply put, they went monolithic with this one because it's not going to be the last entry in the lineup. They certainly didn't drop the multi approach, but I put it that way, because they might be changing up how they were approaching it before. In what way? Well, before the chip sizes were asyncronous. Small and big. Now, they're gonna go probably something more like these being the 'small' or possibly 'medium' dies, and then start doing multi approach of medium+medium until just a single big monolithic die is released as a halo product, and then finally a multi-big setup for the enthusiasts. 9080 series will probably be the multi-medium setup, and the 9090 will be where the big ones show up. If we get a 9060 series or less, that will probably be where the small ones show up, or the worst binned 9070's, etc. The XT monikers are probably getting treated more properly to how they were being treated once upon a time ago, where they actually meant something in terms of performance. The XT moniker got its start as an architecture naming scheme back in 2012 or so. It got bumped into lineup naming later on like we see it used more recently comparatively. This is part of why I figure they may have 4 sizes of dies, not just 2 or 3 or even 1. They used the same die for the 9070 and XT, just different bins it seems. If that 9070 die is it's worst bins so far for that die, then the XT would be its better or best bins. This means to me, that the 9080 with a larger die will almost certainly be a lineup addition later on in the rough 6 month range with some early leaks like usual. And if they follow suit with doing the same thing all over again, then I have to figure at some level that there must be yet one more larger die for the higher end stuff they say they aren't targeting, but probably also aren't leaving behind all together. They'll just save it til last likely. And likewise, if we see entry level below 9070 territory at all come out, it's probably going to be carrying a smaller die than the 9070. Again, binning seems to make this obvious. 

As for why they emphasize the mid range right now? As I see it, they know they have a history of being just a little behind Nvidia, and now are capitalizing on that by playing coy about having something in the works that could possibly meet or beat Nvidia currently instead of being a step back like usual. They also probably know that if they let the news out too soon, Nvidia will just ramp up production of something better again. Seen them play this game before in a similar manner, so I don't put it past them.

comments.text:
5:20 so I did the power consumption maths out of curiosity, and...

CUs : 64/56=8/7(14.29%) more compute units.

Clocks : 2.97/2.52=33/28(17.86%) faster. 

Power consumption : 220*(8/7)*(33/28)=296 watts.

There are only eight watts unaccounted for (2% difference when accounting for CU count and clock speed), meaning that overall, these cards are still WELL within their efficiency curves, and both might overclock shockingly well. Hell, wouldn't be surprised if some crazed guy manages to get a 9070 to 9070xt performance or almost.

And on Green team Blackwell is literally just overclocked Lovelace, this is exilirating.

Edit : aaaand they ruined it. The 9070 is just 50$ cheaper and I don't even need a calculator this time to know the price performance of it will be worse than the 9070xt if they keep it that way. Damnit. Also added percentile number on the fractions to make it easier to follow.

comments.text:
The pricing is still too high for them to shift the market share. At the current price, it will sell well among current AMD customers who are looking to upgrade from an older AMD GPU, but it will not shift people away from Nvidia. A person looking to upgrade from an RTX 2070 or GTX 1080, will be looking at an RTX 5070 ti, or holding out for a 5070 ti super.
On the other hand, if AMD would have done something like pushed the 9070 XT down to $479 (bringing back pre-mining price scaling), and the  and the 9070 down to $400, then all of a sudden, everyone who is not looking for something top of the line, will be looking at AMD's offerings, regardless of if they were previously an Nvidia fan.

Simply put, they need to return to the at least some adjusted for inflation price scaling from the GTX days, and that will allow for them to get everyone on a budget who doesn't have an absolute need for a specific Nvidia feature.

I don't really understand this positivity... is it just wishful thinking?
Why is AMD comparing their card to the 7900GRE? That's not the previous generation's topcard, aren't they just trying to downplay the fact that it's not quite looking so good compared to the 7900 XT and XTX?
Also I'm not sure what the prices have been for the 7900XT in the US, but over here in my country it looks like maybe the 9070XT might be a little cheaper than the 7900XT, if the msrp really is what they will be going for... and it's a little more powerful. But it has less memory. I mean, you get better raytracing and AI... but, really? Is this what we've come to that we get excited for this?
I mean sure, if you're really in need of an upgrade I guess it's nice if this becomes a good option, but you could have just bought a 7900XT somewhere in the past couple years. I got mine a year and a half ago, and this looks like barely an upgrade to me (and a downgrade in memory, really, Nvidia gets dunked on for this all the time, but if AMD does it it's ok?)
I know this generation's AMD cards is not targeted at people like me who already had a highend card from last generation, but still... it's all just so underwhelming. And that's only if AMD's promises turn out to be true.

comments.text: @adrian7856  nothing keeps up with UE5 atm because it is, for lack a of a better word, "immature" as all hell, and hardly any dev has optimised their games correctly for it. Lumen, ONLY looks good in tech demos, and controlled environments, and nobody is even using the UE5 nanite tech properly, if at all, and honestly. I've played some very recent games using "just" UE4, and they run and play soo much better, and the difference in quality is not worth the performance overhead, and it's well known shader compilations and blah blah blah yes they can  and are done at startup, sometimes, but doesn't always fix the issues and blah blah - UE5 is gonna be a joke for the next 4-5 years, it needs to mature, and there's not a lot of GPU power thats going to fix that. The "problem", is that it's one of the most accessible game engines to use at the moment, and with the push for graphical fidelity, publishers are just pushing their devs towards the next big thing to keep that gravy train rolling, and not using the tools correctly or giving them the time to learn... So I am sorry for replying to your comment... it's Friday night, I've had a few drinks - But, I totally agree with you that a f*** 3070 ti or otherwise, should be able to run anything still today - it's even worse when you see the side-by-sides of whatever the consoles are trying to do atm with the dynamic resolution scaling and making everything in the distance blurry as hell 🤣 im so sorry 😮‍💨

comments.text: what drives me nuts is that originally I understood the concept or ray tracing and tensor cores to be that they handle all the ray tracing so you DON'T lose performance in game, and we haven't gotten even close to that point yet.
comments.author: @IWLGaming

comments.text: @IWLGaming  not really. The concept is to run much more compute insensitive ray tracing in real time, instead of the devs running it ahead of time for "baked in" lighting. It's much more a dev pipeline change than a user experience change. But the promise is that eventually every game, even from small dev teams, could have AAA quality lighting at a fraction of the cost
comments.author: @wynandt2

comments.text: my take on this with a small bit of knowledge of graphics programming is this: its likely possible to use raytracing this way, exclusively using the additional hardware to somewhat improve reflections etc, but that would require game studios to still spend effort on the non-raytraced lighting and reflection trickery from before raytracing being as common as it is now, and to apply raytracing much more selectively and in a limited capacity. The issue is that most steps in a rendering pipeline can't really run at the same time, so if you have a normal render of, say, 8ms frametime (120hz) without raytracing, you probably can't run the raytracing at the same time as that normal render, so instead of a total of 8ms with raytracing running for 4ms at the same time as that, you get 8ms + 4ms for a total of 12ms frametime. It's not that simple at all, but its a good way to visualize why this happens.

comments.text:
As much as their reviews of AMD products come off as "fanboi", the last GPU I bought from AMD was the 5700XT, and their review was 100% spot on.  I didn't get anywhere near the performance people were claiming(overkill for 1080p? lol), it took 6 months for them to fix the drivers to the point where it didn't randomly black screen while watching Youtube videos.  The temps were insane too, and it you spun the fans anywhere past 60% it sounded like a jet on the tarmac, but any less than that and you were pushing 90c under load, and 60+ at idle.  There's a reason why the most commonly used AMD GPU on the Steam hardware survey is still the 580.

That said, I hope this goes well for AMD, but 5070 levels of performance for $600 isn't enough to get me off my $300 used 3080.

comments.text:
2:50 Fantastic commitment to the pun there. Whoever made that piece of B-roll deserves a cookie (the tasty type, not the sell-your-data type).

Honestly though, this has me cautiously optimistic. As long as this is reasonably close to what they're saying, and is available at or near MSRP, that's a solid win for AMD. $599 is still higher than I was hoping for, and the non-XT should absolutely be $499 ($50 price tier gaps at that kind of price make no sense whatsoever - they matter at $2-300, not $500+), but if the performance is as promised, this should be decent value. And the performance gains they're promising here have me rather excited for lower tier cards on this architecture, as this could make for a great RX 9060 (and hopefully 9050) series. Only time will tell of course, but I've got an uSFF build lying unused in pieces right now that would be a perfect fit for a ~150W >200mm ~$200-250 GPU.

comments.text:
I don't know why reviewers always fail to realize the decoy effect marketers were employing with the likes of the 7900 XT and now the 9070.  AMD doesn't want you to buy the lower cost one but have it priced where it's at purely as a decoy to try making it more palatable for people to spend the little bit of extra money for a 7900 XTX or now a 9070 XT.  If their manufacturing yields were perfect they'd likely not even offer the cut down version but it's an easy way to recoup some costs and reduce waste.  After the initial sales push and inventory builds up for the cheaper version (it's not like they want to purposefully fuse off good silicon to increase the availability of their cheaper card) then they'll drop the price.

The 9070 XT is an appealing $400 card and the only reason it looks good to reviewers at $600 is because Nvidia's pricing scheme is crazy and a $550 version makes the $600 version slightly more palatable.  All in all though the decoy effect made way more sense for the pricing of the 7900 XTX than it does here and as excited as I am to want to build a 9800X3D and 9070 XT upgrade there's no way I'm going to do it at MSRP so guess I'll just wait another year or two to upgrade as long as my X370 motherboard survives.

comments.text:
Being fake or not, frame generation is indeed something really useful. In the games I used it, my experience has always been rock solid, pure satisfaction. And I don't even use it for the sake of very high frame rates, I use it just for the sake of buttery smooth 60fps gameplay while reducing power consumption and heat generation by a large margin. In Stalker 2, my RTX 4070 TI Super draws 150w less power (from 250w to 100w, give or take, and the CPU also gets a considerable reduction in power consumption, but less expressive than the GPU), just by using frame gen, while keeping that delicious constant 60fps and with ZERO input lag felt .

And to be honest, I really hope that, by the next generation of videogame consoles, 30fps gaming will be a thing of the past, because of AI upscale and frame generation.

comments.text:
For me to switch from Team Green to Team Red, the 9070 XT would need to be $500, and the 9070 would have to be $400. Given that the 5070 is expected to launch at $550, I assume that's AMD's direct competition.

Let’s be real—DLSS, Frame Generation, and Ray Tracing aren’t going anywhere. Would I trade those features for slightly better performance at a slightly higher price? No. You can’t RMA a GPU just because it underperforms. AMD needs to recognize that they’re in the same position as Intel right now—if they want to compete, they need to offer ridiculous value.

Honestly, Nvidia doesn’t have any real competition. If AMD were smart, they’d focus on attracting console gamers as a new market since they clearly can’t get their prices low enough to pull people away from Team Green.

comments.text: Not to excited about RDNA4. It's just RDNA3.5 with 'ai' and more dedicated ray-tracing 'stuff'. Meh. What's got me excited is either 4.5 or RDNA5, because it'll have DDR6 ram compatibility. For mobile gaming, that 'should' be an actual double in performance of RDNA3.5, which 'should' be quite insane. Onboard graphics will match lower-mid tier (admittedly two gen old) dedicated graphics cards, as long as you have plenty of ram to allocate to the gpu on the all-in-one die. And if they let you overclock/shoot more wattage at the thing, it'll be a beast, and possibly even match a half-grade higher(ie. going from 2060 to 2060 Super).

comments.text: Am interested in AFMF 2.1, which for those who don't know is a tech to force frame gen in titles without native FSR 3 support. Works in any DX 11+, OpenGL and Vulkan games and also can be used for games that have 60FPS lock like Yakuza 3-5 remasters. I've been using AFMF 2 with satisfying results, tho admittedly I don't tend to notice frame gen unless its really bad. of course it won't be as good as native FSR support and since it doesn't get data from the game it can't ignore UI like native can but still a nice option to have.

comments.text: @AzraelAlpha The 780M barely beats a GTX-1050ti (launch price $140) from almost a decade ago. APUs are not equivalent to budget GPUs, and a far cry from a reasonable replacement. We need graphics cards at that same $100-150 range again, and while I'm at it we need game devs to stop treating the existence of upscaling and now framegen as excuses to not optimize games. comments.text:
If they stockpiled prior to launch and built up their inventory (possibly in anticipation of tariffs) then there’s also a chance that they can flood the market with enough cards that it’s impossible to scalp.  Nintendo is supposedly doing something similar with the Switch 2, because that’s the last thing they want.  When manufacturers do stuff like that and have more inventory than scalpers can afford to buy, then it makes it pointless for them to even try speculating on these.

If that’s the plan and it works, scalpers are going to be lucky if they can offload them without taking a loss.  The really good news for Normies who want to get into PC gaming is that pre-builts will actually ship with the latest GPU models, unlike the way things have been going for years with them still selling affordable prebuilts with previous gen GPUs.

comments.text:
I feel like people are just fanboying for one side or the other, and there are just more Nvidia fanboys that AMD. Doesn't make any sense to me. I do have concerns about AMD this generation, though they mostly revolve around the fact that they are so late to the smart upscaling game. Even if the new FSR is competitive with DLSS 4 (and lets be honest, it won't be), they still have to play serious catch up with adoption and implementation infrastructure. Intel's XESS is ahead of them.

I know some people roll their eyes at smart features and do have some legitimate complaints about them, but after being hands on with DLSS 4, I know I'm sold on smart AA and upscaling as the future, and it's a really important aspect when considering a new purchase. If it weren't for that, I'd have a hard time even considering team green for my next build. But factoring it in, AMD does need to blow Nvidia out of the water in terms of price to performance currently in order for me to truly consider a red build. Thankfully, they do appear to be set up to accomplish that.

I do forsee AMD's new smart FSR aging really well and accelerating in adoption over time, but to make the purchase on that assumption is poor judgement as a consumer in my eyes.

comments.text: 600$ has never really been flagship money. The top tier back in the day was 1000-1500$ for a dual gpu card, like the 3870x2 4870x2 or the 5990, or the 7990, 295x2 were all this price. Secondly, top end was 2-4 cards, not just 1. Lastly, card bill of materials, IE the PCB, mosfets, caps, component costs, a current midrange costs more to make than a 1080ti cost 8 years ago. As for the silicon, the die sizes may be smaller at each pricepoint, but since the 1080ti came out, a wafer was 7000$, 2-4k prior, a current wafer is over 3x the price at 20k+. The 80s and 90 class cards are replacements for old dual gpu cards, not 80 class cards.

comments.text: @ The 80 and 90 series cards ARE the halo cards. The 70ti/70xt are today what the 1080ti was previously. When you look at all the factors, the cost of the silicon die, watts, number of power channels, cooler size/capacity, PCB size, layers and cost, it lines up with the high end 80 series cards from 7 years ago. You can't just look at die size, remember, silicon costs 3x as much with EUV lithography, a 650mm die then cost the same as a 300mm die today. Put a 7900xtx or a 4080/4090 next to even a rog strix 1080ti, the 1080ti looks midrange size at best. My rog strix 1080ti was 800$, the best of the 1080ti, and the card physically is identical to a 6700xt. They're both 250-300w cards, same pcb size, same power delivery and the die costs about the same due to lithography advances becoming much more expensive.

comments.text: @icy1007  the USD cost of gold doubled. Gold didn't suddenly double in value. The purchasing power of the USD decreased significantly. Look at the price of silver which maintained a steady USD cost. Silver is famously inefficient as a store of value or an investment, for losing value over time because it's easy to get. The purchasing power of the USD decreased at a rate that silver's price stayed the same. Silver's value didn't stay the same. The USD decreased with it.
comments.author: @CounterKazan

comments.text: @icy1007  I posted a reply but it's gone. The price of gold, as well as most things, including eggs and dairy practically doubled in 5 years. Meanwhile the price of silver stayed relatively the same. How does silver, a metal known for getting cheaper over time and thus being a poor investment, maintain the same USD cost? The purchasing power of the USD decreased at the same rate as silver's value.
comments.author: @CounterKazan

comments.text:
@Justin-mt3mk  I'm sorry but you're just wrong. The lack of availability isn't to squeeze more dollars out of you or me, it's to manufacture more enterprise cards with massively greater profit margins (to squeeze more dollars out of THEM). For about 2x the silicon as a 5090, they can sell a product that sells for ~20x more, and do it IN BULK.

Your theory imagines Nvidia giggling maniacally over your spare change; in reality, they barely care. The only reason they keep investing is gaming GPUs because the gaming market has consistently opened up NEW markets for them: AI/ML, augmented reality/simulation, special effects rendering, etc.
